content.webTitle: Death toll rises as floods devastate Russia

fields.headline: Death toll rises as floods devastate Russia
fields.bodyText: The death toll from floods that have devastated southern Russia and other parts of Europe rose to 40 yesterday, with Russia's Black sea coast accounting for most of the victims. Sixteen of those killed in Russia were found in the village of Shirokaya Balka, near the Black sea port of Novorossiisk, said Marina Ryklina, a spokeswoman for the emergency services. On Thursday, a two-metre wall of water engulfed the village of Nizhnaya Bakanskaya in southern Russia. Rescue workers managed to save two people trapped under a collapsed house, according to officials. Rescuers discovered the body of a young girl in the nearby town of Abrau-Dyurso. They are looking for six others who had been camping in the area. Four other bodies were found in the village of Dyurso. The region, which is filled with camps and resorts, is a popular holiday destination in the summer. Thursday's heavy rains forced the evacuation of at least 600 people, destroyed 20 homes and damaged 70 others in eight villages near Novorossiisk, said another emergency services spokeswoman, Irina Andriyanova. Authorities were evacuating people from Shirokaya Balka, Abrau-Dyurso and other nearby villages yesterday as further heavy rain and strong winds hit the area, threatening more flooding, said Leonid Nardekov, an official at the Krasnodar region emergencies department. In the Czech Republic, a 19-year-old girl was missing after a raft carrying her and two friends overturned in a swollen river near Rokycany, 55 miles south-west of Prague. Authorities were searching for a man whose car was swept away in a river in Kaplice, 105 miles south of the capital. On Thursday, a 21-year-old Czech student was killed when a falling tree crushed a cottage, and about 2,000 people were evacuated from flooded homes in southern Bohemia. Officials said that a 51-year-old firefighter had suffered a fatal heart attack during a rescue operation Tabor, 60 miles south of Prague. In south-west Romania, a 62-year-old man and an eight-year-old boy were killed when floodwaters swept through their villages. In Bulgaria, state radio reported that two farmers were killed by lightning. AP
